page.title: 07DOWNLAND AND THE ARUN GAP
page.content: The river Arun meanders through the gap it has made for itself in the chalk of the South Downs. Arundel town guards the gap at its south end and four isolated farming hamlets on cul-de-sac roads are dotted around the edge of the Downs overlooking the wide valley. Water meadows provide grazing for cattle and large areas to the east on the Downs bear crops, mainly of grain. To the west of the river the Downs have been enclosed by one of the Dukes of Norfolk to provide a deer park. There are no longer any deer in the park, but it provides a recreational area very little different from the rest of the Downs. Scheduled replanting preserves the wooded areas.
